text.p: Turkey is planning to spend $150 billion over 30 years until the year 2030 for projects to modernise its army, a senior defence official said on Wednesday.
"The total value of projects proposed to modernise the Turkish Armed Forces by 2030 is about $150 billion," said the senior official, who declined to be named.
He said the government would spend about $5 billion each year for the projects, which he declined to give details on.

"Turkey is already spending about $2.5 to $3 billion every year for defence and we are targeting to double appropriations allocated to the defence industry through increases in the defence industry fund and the budget," he told Reuters.
Deputy Prime Minister Tansu Ciller also told her party meeting on Wednesday that Turkey planned investments worth $150 billion for defence but she did not give any other details.
Turkey, which has the second biggest army in NATO after the United States, has almost completed a $10-billion defence industry plan, which it began in 1986 to modernise its army.
The plan included equipping the army with modern weapons, producing fighter aircraft and electronic warfare equipment.
